learning_outcomes.description: Explain the value of, and apply, structured decision-making and prioritisation approaches to conservation planning and management problems
Explain key actors involved in conservation planning and management and their roles, and how different values can be incorporated into these processes
Source and synthesise disparate forms of evidence to guide conservation planning and decision-making
Explain the importance of and potential for Traditional Knowledge to inform and underpin conservation management

Map out and analyse the context and scope of a conservation problem and create a clearly-articulated management plan aligned with the Open Standards for Conservation, including consideration of links to human wellbeing

Apply critical and creative thinking skills to inform discussion and debate over current real-world challenges in conservation planning and management such as innovative financing, evaluating conservation effectiveness, and management of fire

assessments.task_description:
Notes on Assignments 1 and 2: These assignments involve developing a conservation project plan for a region, following the Open Standard for the Practice of Conservation guidelines. The final plan will be submitted as Assignment 2. Assignment 1 involves submitting a draft of the first part of the plan, allowing an opportunity for feedback that you can draw upon to improve the final, complete plan.

For your conservation project plan, you can choose any region (such as a landscape or a protected area). While you should choose a region for which there is a good amount of accessible literature, try to avoid choosing one for which there is already an available conservation project plan that follows the structure we request here, as it is important for your thought processes to be original and not simply rewording a plan that already exists. 

Your conservation management plan should be informed by your understanding of the Open Standards for the Practice Conservation and related content, based on the tutorial sessions, set references, and wider reading. It is also highly recommended that you visit the conservationstandards.org website, which has lots of useful resources.

You should use careful literature searches to identify both journal articles and ‘grey’ literature such as reports and existing conservation plans that can inform your understanding of the region and its values, the threats they face, and conservation actions that may be appropriate and effective.

Note: more information and guidance will be provided in practical classes and via the course Blackboard site during semester. 

Assignment 1: Draft Conservation Project Plan: Defining Your Project

1200 words maximum – 15%

The draft of the first sections of your conservation project plan will be submitted as Assignment 1. You will receive feedback on this section, allowing you to revise it if necessary before including it in your final conservation project plan to be submitted as Assignment 2 later in the semester. Assignment 1 must include the following three sections (page numbers refer to the relevant sections in the Open Standards for the Practice of Conservation Version 5.0):

1. Project scope & focal conservation values

  • The project scope, including a brief text description and map of your region, as well as the timeframe for the project (page 17).
  • A simple, one-sentence statement of the overall vision of your project (page 18)
  • Description of two focal values and justification for their selection (page 19). These should include one biodiversity focal value and one human wellbeing focal value.

2. Project team and interested parties

  • Based on these two focal values, describe and justify the key partners and interested parties in the development and implement of a conservation management plan for this focal value in this region (page 15). The text should make it clear which organisation or group would be leading the plan and should supported by a table summarising the role of each party (project team, advisor, decision maker, funder, affected party or other), the skills, experience or resources they would contribute, and what their main priorities or concerns might be.

3. Stresses and critical threats

  • In the text, summarise the direct threats (pressures) to both of your focal values (page 23).
  • For your biodiversity focal value, in a simple table, classify the direct threats to each value based on their severity and scope.
  • Based on your analysis, identify the two to three critical threats for your biodiversity focal value only

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online submission by Turnitin only by the due date and time. Refer to Blackboard for the submission link. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets are required. Submission via email is not accepted.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Notes on Assignments 1 and 2: These assignments involve developing a conservation project plan for a region, following the Open Standard for the Practice of Conservation guidelines. The final plan will be submitted as Assignment 2. Assignment 1 involves submitting a draft of the first part of the plan, allowing an opportunity for feedback that you can draw upon to improve the final, complete plan.

For your conservation project plan, you can choose any region (such as a landscape or a protected area). While you should choose a region for which there is a good amount of accessible literature, try to avoid choosing one for which there is already an available conservation project plan that follows the structure we request here, as it is important for your thought processes to be original and not simply rewording a plan that already exists. 

Your conservation management plan should be informed by your understanding of the Open Standards for the Practice Conservation and related content, based on the tutorial sessions, set references, and wider reading. It is also highly recommended that you visit the conservationstandards.org website, which has lots of useful resources.

You should use careful literature searches to identify both journal articles and ‘grey’ literature such as reports and existing conservation plans that can inform your understanding of the region and its values, the threats they face, and conservation actions that may be appropriate and effective.

Note: more information and guidance will be provided in practical classes and via the course Blackboard site during semester. 

Assignment 2: Full Conservation Project Plan

4000 words maximum (including parts 1-8)

You must include Parts 1-3, as developed in Assignment 1, as the first part of this Assessment item. You may revise the material from Assignment 1 before you submit it as part of Assignment 2. In addition, you must include in your submission Parts 4-8. Thus, Assignment 2 includes the following: (page numbers refer to the relevant sections in the Open Standards for the Practice of Conservation Version 5.0):

1. Project scope & focal conservation values

  • The project scope, including a brief text description and map of your region, as well as the timeframe for the project (page 17).
  • A simple, one-sentence statement of the overall vision of your project (page 18)
  • Description of two focal values and justification for their selection (page 19). These should include one biodiversity focal value and one human wellbeing focal value.

2. Project team and interested parties

  • Based on these two focal values, describe and justify the key partners and interested parties in the development and implement of a conservation management plan for this focal value in this region (page 15). The text should make it clear which organisation or group would be leading the plan and should supported by a table summarising the role of each party (project team, advisor, decision maker, funder, affected party or other), the skills, experience or resources they would contribute, and what their main priorities or concerns might be.

3. Stresses and critical threats

  • In the text, summarise the direct threats (pressures) to both of your focal values (page 23).
  • For your biodiversity focal value, in a simple table, classify the direct threats to each value based on their severity and scope.
  • Based on your analysis, identify the two to three critical threats for your biodiversity focal value only

4. Situation analysis and model

  • With supporting text, and drawing from the information collected for Part 3, create a graphical situation model (conceptual diagram) of your hypothesized linkages between indirect and direct threats (page 26), including the critical threats and both your biodiversity and human health focal values. 

5. Goals

  • Outline one or more SMART goals for your focal values (page 33), briefly justifying your choices.

6. Key intervention points and actions

  • Describe and justify the key opportunities for intervention in the situation where you have the potential to influence and which provide the best opportunities to improve the outcomes for your focal values (page 35)
  • Identify the specific actions that you propose to take under this project plan and summarise in table form which Project team members will lead in each case
  • Include your situation model from Part 4, but with the addition of the indirect threats, key intervention points and hypothesized linkages between actions, threats, and your focal values.

7. Monitoring, evaluation, and learning plan

  • Considering the situation model that you have updated for Part 6, select and justify a series of indicators to measure that will help you monitor and evaluate the performance of your project (page 47). Indicators should be measurable, reliably linked to the value, outcome, or action that they are indicating, and sensitive to changes within the timeframe of your project.
  • The indicators should include those that allow you to identify whether your goal is achieved, but also allow you to monitor intermediate steps and outcomes
  • Include a table (supported by text) identifying each indicator, what methods will be used to measure it, and the current and desirable states of that indicator
  • Include commentary on any monitoring outcomes that would suggest that the project is not on track and what type of review that these suboptimal outcomes should trigger

8. Caveats and operational logistics

  • Briefly summarise any caveats, such as which assumptions are being made? What needs to occur outside of the actions the project team can take?
  • Consider what resources and further plans will be needed to carry out your project in terms of human capacity, skills and other non-financial resources, funding, and social safeguards (page 53)?

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online submission by Turnitin only by the due date and time. Refer to Blackboard for the submission link. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets are required. Submission via email is not accepted.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
A 2-hour examination will be held during the end of semester examination period. It will comprise a series of multiple choice, short answer, and longer answer questions.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
